content:
This problem really looks good. However, I found one an 'intuitive' solution which can easily pass tests and validators, but it's not correct for this problem. In this solution, stopping the loop is when the number consists of one digit (except the first iteration).
My solution in Python:
n = int(input())
for i in range(n):
    c = x = input()
    if len(c)==1:
        c='0'+c
    while(len(c)!=1):
        c = str(sum(int(i)**2 for i in c))
    print(x+(' :)' if c=='1'else ' :('))

But if you input 1112, this solution will output "unhappy", but 1112 is 'happy'(1112->7->49->97->130->10->1).
Thanks your feed back. I should include that test case and may be some more similar cases.
